results.title: Facing Hurricane and Wildfire Seasons, FEMA Is Already Worn Out
results.abstract: Multiple missions, combined with years of record disasters, have strained the agency — and scientists predict an unusually severe disaster season ahead.
results.byline: By Christopher Flavelle and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

multimedia.caption: Rescue personnel searched debris and destroyed buildings in the aftermath of Hurricane Michael in Mexico Beach, Fla., in 2018.
Rescue personnel searched debris and destroyed buildings in the aftermath of Hurricane Michael in Mexico Beach, Fla., in 2018.

results.title: Even Amid a Pandemic, More Than 40 Million People Fled Their Homes
results.abstract: Storms, floods, wildfires and to a lesser degree, conflict, uprooted millions globally in 2020 — the largest human displacement in more than a decade.

multimedia.caption: The evacuation of Dhal Char village in Bangladesh as Cyclone Amphan approached in 2020.

results.title: Scientists Predict an ‘Above Normal’ Atlantic Hurricane Season
results.abstract: The forecast, which follows a record season in 2020, arrives as hurricanes are becoming more destructive over time.

multimedia.caption: Lake Pontchartrain in New Orleans as Hurricane Zeta approached in October. There were so many named storms last year, NOAA had to use Greek letters to name some.

results.title: Intruder Pests May Drain Trillions From Africa’s Economies, Study Finds
results.abstract: Invasive species could cost the agricultural sector more than $3.5 trillion across the continent, a new study estimated.

multimedia.caption: A farmer near Sokoto in northwestern Nigeria. Corn, cassava and tomatoes have been hit hard by invasive species on the continent.
A farmer near Sokoto in northwestern Nigeria. Corn, cassava and tomatoes have been hit hard by invasive species on the continent.

results.title: David Wake, Expert on Salamanders and Evolution, Dies at 84
results.abstract: While on a college field trip to collect beetles, he found salamanders. He became an authority and later grew alarmed by the disappearance of many amphibians.

multimedia.caption: The biologist David Wake with a jar of preserved salamanders in the 1970s. “If you sat down to dinner with him,” a former student said, “he would talk about and describe salamanders and you’d want to drop everything to go with him.”

results.title: What Can and Can’t Be Learned From a Doctor in China Who Pioneered Masks
results.abstract: Dr. Wu Lien-Teh helped change the course of a plague epidemic in the early 20th century and promoted the use of masks as a public health tool.

results.title: A New York Museum Staple Gets a New Glimmer
results.abstract: At the redesigned Allison and Roberto Mignone Halls of Gems and Minerals, which opens June 12, the evolution of minerals is front and center.

multimedia.caption: The redesigned displays are spacious and bright, putting the emphasis on the stars of the show, the minerals and gems.

results.title: Severe Drought, Worsened by Climate Change, Ravages the American West
results.abstract: Heat and shifting weather patterns have intensified wildfires and sharply reduced water supplies across the Southwest, the Pacific Coast and North Dakota.

multimedia.caption: A shrinking Folsom Lake in El Dorado Hills, Calif., this month left boat docks high and dry.
A shrinking Folsom Lake in El Dorado Hills, Calif., this month left boat docks high and dry.

results.title: Blazes That Refuse to Die: ‘Zombie Fires’
results.abstract: With a changing climate, fires in far northern forests that smolder throughout winter and erupt again in spring could become more common, a new study suggests.

multimedia.caption: The Bogus Creek Fire in the Yukon Delta National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska, a state where the vast majority of carbon emissions from fires come from burning soil.
multimedia.copyright: Matt Snyder/Alaska Division of Forestry, via Associated Press

results.title: Here Is Who’s Behind the Global Surge in Single-Use Plastic
results.abstract: A new report shows that a surprisingly small number of big companies and banks are behind the manufacturing and financing of much of the world’s single-use plastic.
results.byline: By Michael Corkery and Somini Sengupta

multimedia.caption: Collecting plastic at a landfill on Sulawesi in Indonesia. Half the world’s single-use plastic is made by 20 big companies, researchers said.

results.title: Irish Hospitals Are Latest to Be Hit by Ransomware Attacks
results.abstract: Hospitals in Ireland, New Zealand and Scripps Health in San Diego are reeling from digital extortion attacks.
results.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and Adam Satariano

results.title: An Old Conflict With Digital Twists
results.abstract: How the latest violence between Israelis and Palestinians encapsulates the best and worst of digital life.

results.abstract: Zhang Yiming steered ByteDance to become China’s first truly globally successful internet company.

results.title: Should Alexa Read Our Moods?
results.abstract: The time to debate the power of voice technology is now. (Before Alexa starts suggesting comfort foods.)

results.abstract: The pandemic made health care workers a new target for having their personal information shared online, often with real-world consequences.

results.title: Mob Violence Against Palestinians in Israel Is Fueled by Groups on WhatsApp
results.abstract: Israeli extremists have formed more than 100 new groups on the Facebook-owned encrypted messaging app in recent days to target attacks.

results.title: After Media Detour, AT&T Confronts Old Problems
results.abstract: Following its spinoff of WarnerMedia, AT&T is back to primarily being a wireless company, with all of the challenges that entails.
